text: ..or he. ..or they.
or it :man-shrugging:
I prefer Finnish and Hungarian when it comes to third-person singular pronouns.

elements.text: I prefer Finnish and Hungarian when it comes to third-person singular pronouns.

text: Hän
Hän is an excellent pronoun, except in practise I often tend to you ‘se’, which means it.

elements.text: Hän is an excellent pronoun, except in practise I often tend to you ‘se’, which means it.

text: ..which is of course incorrect.
English should learn from Finnish.
Pronunciation is so much easier in Finnish.

elements.text: Pronunciation is so much easier in Finnish.

text: If you want to hear what the result would sound like, you can watch the Hydraulic Press Channel on YT.

elements.text: If you want to hear what the result would sound like, you can watch the Hydraulic Press Channel on YT.

text: Swedish also now has ‘hen’ which is a gender-neutral version of han/hon. I wonder if it’s used much in the wild?

elements.text: Swedish also now has ‘hen’ which is a gender-neutral version of han/hon. I wonder if it’s used much in the wild?

text: Interesting.
The downside of finnish is native speakers tend to confuse he/she every now and then in english :smile:

elements.text: The downside of finnish is native speakers tend to confuse he/she every now and then in english

text: Many people who speak Chinese/Korean/Japanese commit the same error.

elements.text: Many people who speak Chinese/Korean/Japanese commit the same error.

text:
Yeah it can also happen with native Filipino speakers as well when speaking English. 

I wonder if native English speakers have trouble with inclusive-we and exclusive-we when speaking othee languages that have that language feature

elements.text:
Yeah it can also happen with native Filipino speakers as well when speaking English. 

I wonder if native English speakers have trouble with inclusive-we and exclusive-we when speaking othee languages that have that language feature

text: ^ I find that to be the case, it's hard to pick the right word on reflex

elements.text: ^ I find that to be the case, it's hard to pick the right word on reflex

text:
I've been learning Māori which has inclusive vs exclusive AND single/dual/plural - so there are different words for all the following...
• I
• you (s)
• they (s)
• we two including you
• we two excluding you
• those two
• we three+ including you
• we three+ excluding you
• those three+

elements.text: I've been learning Māori which has inclusive vs exclusive AND single/dual/plural - so there are different words for all the following...

text: we two excluding you :ahhhhhhh:
I did some Japanese earlier, though very little, I remember they have pronouns for that thing closer to you and that thing closer to me.

elements.text: I did some Japanese earlier, though very little, I remember they have pronouns for that thing closer to you and that thing closer to me.

text: Ari-gato is also ‘thank you’.
Pacific people migrated from SE Asia originally, so there are some definite language similarities across the region. Māori also has "thing by me" vs "thing by you" vs "thing away from both of us".

elements.text: Pacific people migrated from SE Asia originally, so there are some definite language similarities across the region. Māori also has "thing by me" vs "thing by you" vs "thing away from both of us".

text: Korean also has that thing closer to you and that thing closer to me and that thing far away as well.

elements.text: Korean also has that thing closer to you and that thing closer to me and that thing far away as well.
